data.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec><jats:title>Background</jats:title><jats:p>As antibiotic resistance is becoming a major problem nowadays in a treatment of infections, bacteriophages (also known as phages) seem to be an alternative. However, to be used in a therapy, their life cycle should be strictly lytic. With the growing popularity of Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) technology, it is possible to gain such information from the genome sequence. A number of tools are available which help to define phage life cycle. However, there is still no unanimous way to deal with this problem, especially in the absence of well-defined open reading frames. To overcome this limitation, a new tool is definitely needed.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Results</jats:title><jats:p>We developed a novel tool, called PhageAI, that allows to access more than 10 000 publicly available bacteriophages and differentiate between their major types of life cycles: lytic and lysogenic. The tool included life cycle classifier which achieved 98.90% accuracy on a validation set and 97.18% average accuracy on a test set. We adopted nucleotide sequences embedding based on the Word2Vec with Ship-gram model and linear Support Vector Machine with 10-fold cross-validation for supervised classification. PhageAI is free of charge and it is available at<jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="https://phage.ai/">https://phage.ai/</jats:ext-link>. PhageAI is a REST web service and available as Python package.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title><jats:p>Machine learning and Natural Language Processing allows to extract information from bacteriophages nucleotide sequences for lifecycle prediction tasks. The PhageAI tool classifies phages into either virulent or temperate with a higher accuracy than any existing methods and shares interactive 3D visualization to help interpreting model classification results.</jats:p></jats:sec>
title: PhageAI - Bacteriophage Life Cycle Recognition with Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing
